page.title: 05ECOLOGY FERNDOWN HEATH
page.content: The{heath}mainly consists of heather and gorse, with ferns and clumps of wild grasses interspersed with fir, small oak, elder, willow and silver birch trees. There are many{insects such as ants, beetles, centipedes and woodlice. Some live behind bark or in foliage, or make their homes in fallen tree trunks. There are many different kinds of {birds}living on the heath. The woodpecker for instance drills holes, angling them slightly downwards so the sap will collect in small hollows. This attracts insects which provide another meal. There are many{animals such as foxes, badgers, rabbits, voles, mice, rats and stoats; and {reptiles}such as adders, slowworms, lizards, and harmless grass snakes. Large areas of heath are destroyed every summer by heath fires.
